title: SEO
subtitle: Start from zero and grow step by step with clear words and tiny, real examples.
overview: SEO means Search Engine Optimization. It helps people find your pages on Google and other search engines. In this course you will learn the basics: how search works, keywords, on‑page HTML, site structure, performance, mobile, structured data, and how to measure results. We use simple words and small steps.
content: We focus on practical SEO: write clear titles, useful content, good links, and clean HTML. We also cover technical topics, but in a friendly way. You will see short examples, quick tips, and small quizzes to check your understanding.
prerequisites: Nice to have: basic HTML and how to edit a file
outcomes: Understand how search engines discover, crawl, and index pages
Use on‑page HTML correctly (title, meta description, headings, alt)
Plan keywords by intent and write helpful content
Improve performance, mobile experience, and site structure
Use Search Console and analytics to measure and improve

instructor.name: Ayisha Team
instructor.bio: Frontend engineers and content makers who love clear, useful pages.

lessons.title: What is SEO?
lessons.summary: Learn what SEO is and why helpful pages win.

content.value: SEO helps people find your page. Search engines try to show the most helpful result for a query.
Good SEO is simple: useful content, clear HTML, fast pages, and easy navigation.
There are three parts: on‑page (your content and HTML), off‑page (links from other sites), and technical (crawl, index, performance).
Write for humans first. Search engines reward helpful pages.
We will use short code to show how to set titles, meta descriptions, headings, alt text, and more.

examples.code: A page that clearly answers: "How to change a bike tire" with steps, pictures, and tools.
A page that repeats the keyword many times but gives no real help.
Intro → Steps → Tips → FAQ → Links to related guides

lessons.title: How Search Works
lessons.summary: Crawling, indexing, and ranking in simple words.

content.value: Crawling: bots discover links and download pages.
Indexing: the engine reads your content and stores it to be searched later.
Ranking: for each query, results are ordered based on many signals.
You can help crawling with clean links, sitemaps, and no broken pages.
Keep a simple site structure. Fewer clicks from the home to important pages.

examples.code: Home → Category → Article (the bot follows links and discovers new pages)
A page with no links pointing to it. Hard to discover.
A sitemap.xml lists key URLs to help discovery.

quiz.prompt: A simple aid for crawling is:

lessons.title: Keywords and Search Intent
lessons.summary: Understand queries and user goals to pick topics.

content.value: Keywords are the words people type in search. Intent is the goal behind the query.
Main intents: informational (learn), navigational (go to site), transactional (buy), commercial (compare).
Pick topics that match your users and business. Group related keywords into one helpful page.
Avoid making many thin pages. Make one strong page that answers fully.
Look at the top results. What format do they use? Guide, list, product page, FAQ?

examples.code:
Query: "best running shoes" → commercial (comparison)
Query: "buy nike air" → transactional
Main page: "Home Wi‑Fi Guide" + child pages: setup, security, speed tests
Merge 5 tiny posts into 1 clear, complete guide.

options: Group related keywords into strong pages

lessons.title: On‑Page Basics: Title, Description, Headings
lessons.summary: Set a clear title, meta description, and heading structure.

content.value: Each page needs one clear <title>. It shows in the browser tab and can appear in search results.

<head>
  <title>How to Change a Bike Tire (Step by Step)</title>
  <meta name="description" content="Learn how to change a bike tire with tools, steps, and tips.">
</head>
Use headings (h1..h6) to build a logical outline. One h1 for the main topic, then h2..h3 for sections.

Change a Bike Tire

Tools

Steps

Remove the wheel
Avoid stuffing keywords. Write natural titles and descriptions that match the content.

examples.code: “Homemade Pizza: Easy Recipe for Crispy Crust”
“Pizza, Pizza, Best Pizza Pizza”
h1: Pizza Recipe → h2: Dough → h2: Sauce → h2: Bake

lessons.title: URLs and Site Structure
lessons.summary: Use clean URLs and a simple site tree.

content.value: Use short, readable URLs. Include important words. Avoid long IDs and noise.
Keep a simple structure: home → category → page. Use internal links to connect related pages.
Add breadcrumbs to help users and bots understand location.

1. Home
  2. Bikes
  3. Change Tire
Do not change URLs often. If you must, use 301 redirects to the new URL.

examples.code: /guides/change-bike-tire
/p?id=1234&cat=9&x=abc
A category page that links to all child guides.

lessons.title: Content Quality (Helpfulness)
lessons.summary: Write clear, original content that solves a real need.

content.value: Answer the user’s question fully. Show steps, examples, and warnings when useful.
Use simple words. Cut fluff. Bring your experience and clear structure.
Keep pages fresh. Update when info changes.
Show sources where needed. Build trust.
Add a short summary at the top. Many readers scan first.

examples.code: Intro → Requirements → Steps → Troubleshooting → FAQ
Author bio, updated date, clear contact page
Remove repeated sentences. Keep only what helps.

lessons.title: Images and Media SEO
lessons.summary: Use alt text, file names, and lightweight media.

content.value: Use descriptive file names like cooking-pizza-dough.jpg.
Always write alt that explains the image role. Use empty alt for purely decorative images.
Compress images and use modern formats when possible.
Add captions when helpful (figure + figcaption).
Use width and height to prevent layout shifts.

lessons.title: Internal Linking and Navigation
lessons.summary: Link related pages and guide users with clear anchors.

content.value: Use descriptive anchor text that tells where the link goes.
Link from old pages to new pages on the same topic.
Use nav, lists, and footer links to important areas.
Avoid too many links in one block. Keep it usable.
Add related links at the end of articles to keep users exploring.

examples.code: Set up your home Wi‑Fi
Click here

Related

  • Wi‑Fi Security

options: Users and bots discover more pages

lessons.title: Technical SEO: Crawl, Robots, Sitemaps
lessons.summary: Control crawling and help discovery with simple files.

content.value: robots.txt tells bots what paths they can or cannot crawl.

User-agent: *
Disallow: /admin/
Allow: /
A sitemap lists key URLs for discovery. Keep it updated.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
  <url><loc>https://example.com/</loc></url>
  <url><loc>https://example.com/guides/</loc></url>
</urlset>
Do not block pages you want to rank. robots.txt blocks crawling, not indexing of known URLs.

examples.code:
User-agent: *
Disallow: /admin/

User-agent: *
Allow: /
<urlset>… URLs …</urlset>

quiz.prompt: If you want a page to rank, you should:

lessons.title: Performance and Core Web Vitals
lessons.summary: Fast pages help users and ranking.

content.value: Big images and heavy scripts slow pages. Optimize both.
Avoid layout shifts: set sizes for media, load fonts safely, avoid late DOM changes.
Use caching and compression on the server.
Measure and fix: test on real devices.
Simpler pages are often faster and easier to maintain.

examples.code: Compress, lazy‑load below the fold, serve responsive sizes
Remove unused libraries, split code, defer non‑critical
Reserve space (width/height), avoid CLS spikes

lessons.title: Mobile and UX
lessons.summary: Make pages friendly on phones and tablets.

content.value: Use responsive layout and readable text sizes.
Touch targets should be big enough and spaced well.
Avoid blocking interstitials that cover the content.
Test on different devices and orientations.
Use viewport meta and flexible units for layout.

examples.code: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
Base font size ~16px, good line height
Buttons with at least ~44x44px tappable area

lessons.title: Structured Data (JSON‑LD)
lessons.summary: Add schema markup for rich results.

content.value: Structured data helps search engines understand your page type and parts.
Use JSON‑LD in a <script type="application/ld+json"> block.
Match the visible content. Do not add fake data.
Common types: Article, Product, FAQ, Breadcrumb, Organization.
Validate your markup with online testing tools.

examples.code:
<script type="application/ld+json">{
  "@context":"https://schema.org",
  "@type":"Article",
  "headline":"Homemade Pizza Guide",
  "author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Ana"}
}</script>

<script type="application/ld+json">{
  "@context":"https://schema.org",
  "@type":"BreadcrumbList",
  "itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"name":"Home","item":"/"}]
}</script>

<script type="application/ld+json">{
  "@context":"https://schema.org",
  "@type":"FAQPage",
  "mainEntity":[{"@type":"Question","name":"Is dough hard?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"No. Follow the steps."}}]
}</script>

lessons.title: Local SEO Basics
lessons.summary: Help nearby users find your business.

content.value: Keep the business name, address, and phone (NAP) consistent.
Create a simple contact page with hours and map.
Ask happy customers for honest reviews.
List your business on relevant directories.
Use LocalBusiness schema when it fits.

examples.code: Address, phone, email, hours, map embed
Same format across site and directories
Add name, address, phone in JSON‑LD

lessons.title: Measure and Improve
lessons.summary: Use Search Console and analytics to learn and act.

content.value: Use Search Console to see queries, clicks, and index status.
Check coverage issues and fix errors and redirects.
Use analytics to see what users do on the page.
Make small improvements and re‑check results.
Write down changes and dates. Track what worked.

examples.code: Clicks, impressions, CTR, average position, conversions
Find issue → Fix → Re‑test → Monitor
Start with high‑impact, low‑effort changes
